softwar=
e or papers you can share with more information?

--- In neat@yahoogro=
ups.com, "gbravoescobar" <gbravoescobar@y...> 
wrote:
> 
> Hi,
> 
>     Som=
e months have been since my last mail, I have been 
researching
> two stuff=
s:
> 
> 1)  Use of Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) with NEAT  (see
> http://w=
ww.idsia.ch/~juergen/lstm/ to know more about LSTM).
> 2)  Development of W=
ork methods to use NEAT-LSTM and some 
classifiers
> like Cascade-Adaboost =
to solve real Automation Industry problems 
in a
> feasible way.
> 
> 
> 1)=
 NEAT-LSTM:
> Abstract:
>        The LSTM are a cell of neurons that are ab=
le to store a 
value
> during long periods. That is a problem in all Recurr=
ent Networks,
> values are difficult to store more than 10-50 iterations in=
 the
> network (see LSTM Link for references). 
> 
> 	I put LSTM inside a N=
EAT. The evolution make NEAT to use 
LSTM cells
> in a productive way stori=
ng key values, recovering that values when
> they are useful a forgetting t=
hem  if it is useful (The 3 LSTM cell
> functions).
> 
> 	My analysis of so=
me of the solve problems suggest that LSTM 
helps to
> NEAT in some problem=
s to reduce greatly the searching space 
helping to
> memorize (some times =
to accumulate) some important key events that 
are
> used after to get out =
the right outputs.
> 
> 	An intuitional example about reduction of searchin=
g space is 
serial
> XOR, if you solve serial XOR with NEAT you can see tha=
t the 
solution
> net use recurrent connection to store the first value and=
 later it
> compares with second value in the serial sequence. In my comput=
er 
(P4
> 2,4Ghz) it last around  2 minutes to find a solution with NEAT 
a=
lone.
> However, when I use one LSTM cell in the NEAT-LSTM it last ONLY 5
>=
 SECONDS!!!!!.
> 
> 2)  Improving Work Methods in Real Automation Problems:=

> 
>       Motivation: Evolution systems have been achieving great 
result=
s
> in last years. In my daily work in automation projects business, I
> ha=
ve to face another problem: cost. That is the reason that most of
> the tim=
es the industry try to avoid complex systems. Complex 
systems
> are diffic=
ult to develop, difficult to modify and difficult to
> maintenance. Most of=
 the times, it is the last choosen resource. 
> 
> 	Other problems to use e=
volution systems are the 
uncertainty.  Always,
> there is some likelihood =
that a problem will converge to a 
solution in
> a reasonable time. Some ti=
me we can evaluate it, sizing the 
searching
> space. Other times it very d=
ifficult to size such space. 
Uncertainty
> is a variable related to, what =
is known in business as, risk. 
> 
> 	Some recent experiment as in 
> http:=
//nn.cs.utexas.edu/downloads/papers/whiteson.gecco03.pdf 
suggest
> that a =
way to reduce searching space is to "draw" the guide
> where the
> solution=
 will be searched. Some of my research has gone in that
> direction. In mos=
t of the systems we have deal with, we have some
> previous knowledge about=
 them. My work is focusing in how organize
> such previous knowledge in: de=
cision trees, tasks, abstraction 
levels
> and interdependences among them =
to reduce as much as possible the
> searching space. So the final goal is t=
o find feasibility work 
methods
> and tools to use evolution systems in re=
al automation Industry
> problems.
> 
> Regards.
> 
> Germ=E1n.
